key_points: Only six Supreme Court Justices attended President Biden's swearing-in, marking the first absence of some justices in over 20 years.
Justices Clarence Thomas, Stephen G. Breyer, and Samuel A. Alito Jr. did not attend due to public health concerns amid the COVID pandemic.
The Supreme Court has been operating remotely since March, only gathering in person once for Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's memorial service.
Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. administered the presidential oath to Biden, despite both having opposed Roberts' confirmation in the past.
Justice Sonia Sotomayor administered the oath to Vice President Harris, marking a series of firsts for both officials.
Former senators Biden and Harris have historically voted against the confirmation of six out of the nine current Supreme Court justices.
Biden's attempts to filibuster Alito's nomination and his role in Clarence Thomas's contentious confirmation hearing reflect a history of tension.
Thomas has publicly criticized Biden's conduct during his confirmation hearings, particularly concerning questions about natural law.
Despite past confrontations, Biden reached out to Anita Hill, who accused Thomas of sexual harassment, to express regret for her treatment during the hearings.
The absence of some justices at the inauguration hints at enduring political and personal tensions.
